title.narrative: 6.3 BIRTH REGISTRATION

description.narrative: Output 6.3: The birth registration system has strengthened capacity to scale up the registration of children under age 5 years, with focus on children under 1 year of age., which contributes to Access To Justice, Promotion Of Care, Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being And Justice. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: 6. Children who are victims or at significant risk of violence, abuse, neglect and exploitation, including those in humanitarian settings, receive quality preventive and responsive services from a functioning child protection system at federal level and in targeted states

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 6.3: The birth registration system has strengthened capacity to scale up the registration of children under age 5 years, with focus on children under 1 year of age.

description.narrative: UNICEF recorded progress with developing a decentralized digitalized birth registration system in Nigeria, which we anticipate will be critical to reaching universal birth registration (i.e., 80% of u5 children registered) by 2023. Several measures were taken, including an assessment of the current digitalized system, which led to important recommendations to increase the capacity of registrars, interoperability of the system, and address legal constraints. UNICEF secured political commitment and intersectoral collaboration by setting up a (CRVS) coordination committee and a roadmap to take this process forward. | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:23/12/2021
